div.head: Report:
div.p: The confinement properties of semiconductor nanocrystals (NC's) offer an interesting approach for new light emitter or solar cell devices. One possibility to get a controlled size of NC's is the use of superlattice structures [1][2][3]. For this experiment various samples of (GeO x / SiO 2 ) 19x superlattices, characterized by different GeO x thicknesses and stoichiometries, have been prepared by reactive magnetron sputtering. At ROBL the samples were mounted in a furnace chamber equipped with a semi-spherical Be dome and subsequently annealed at different temperatures under UHV conditions (< 10 -7 mbar) while continuously monitoring the superlattice properties and the Ge NC's formation with x-ray reflectivity (XRR) and grazing incidence x-ray diffraction (GIXRD), respectively.

The onset of GeO x /SiO 2 superlattice degradation as a result of GeO x phase separation strongly depends on the GeO x stoichiometry with a clear tendency towards an enhanced stability of Ge rich GeO x films (x < 1), in agreement to previous experiments (20-02-658 / 667) [4].

The following details are discussed for #169 characterized by a superlattice of (5.2 nm GeO/2.4 nm SiO 2 ) 19x (i.e. x = 1). Ge NC's are formed at annealing at T A = 450째C (see Fig. 1), whereas at T A = 550째C the superlattice starts to degrate which is correlated with a significant Ge loss due to the emanation of volatile GeO. As prooved by RBS, after an annealing at 600째C more than half of the Ge gets lost. Consequently, in GIXRD a clear decrease in the peak area of Ge ( 111) is obtained (Fig. 1). As shown by ex-situ TEM investigations (Fig. 2) the multilayer structure is completely dissolved. The nanocluster distribution are characterized by the formation of large clusters up to 20 nm size and does not show vertical or lateral ordering anymore. GISAXS investigations of the sample 169 annealed to T=500 o C (Fig. 3a) showed a clear peak at Q z =0.895 nm -1 confirming the size of the double layer (GeOx/SiO2) to be 7.02 nm (similar to the XRR results of 7.4 nm). Also the denisty variation lateraly (e.g. the fomation of Ge NC's in the matrix) could be determined to be in the length of Q= 0.25 nm -1 or less. This leads to average particle -particle distance of 25nm or more at T A = 500 o C (Fig. 3b). At 600 o C the GISAXS signal gets very weak due to the loss of the volatile GeO. A strong drop in intensity of the peak at Q z indicates the destroying of the SL structure (Fig. 3b). But also in the signal of the Yonada wing showed a strong decrease in intensity, confirming the GIXRD and the RBS results of the loss of GeO during the annealing to 550-600 o C.

div.head: References:
div.p: [1] S. -0,5 0,0 0,5 0 200 400 600 800 1000 1200 1400 0,5 1,0 1,5 200 400 600 800 1000 1200 1400 Q y (nm -1 ) Intensity (arb.units) Q z (nm -1 ) T A = 500 o C T A = 600 o C Fig. 3a: GISAXS pattern of the superlattice at T=500 o C, the black lines indicate the position of the red lincut, shown in in Fig. 3b. The two upper maxima indicate the average size of the SL double layer, in this case 7.02nm. Fig. 3b: Line cuts obtained from the GISAXS pattern at T A =500 o C(red line, out of Fig.3a) and T A =600 o C(blue line, image not shown here). The upper graph (Q z Linecuts) clearly shows the drop of Intensity at Q z =0.895nm -1 due to the degradation of the superlattice. The loss of scatters (Ge-Atoms) can be also seen in the lower graph ( Q y profiles).

figure.head: Fig. 1 :
figure.figDesc: Fig. 1: GIXRD of # 169 showing the formation of Ge NC's at low annealing temperature and the Ge-loss during annealing above 550째C.

Foss et al., Thin Solid Films 515, (2007), 6381-6384 [2] M.Buljan et al. Phys.Rev.B79, 035310, (2009) [3] M.Buljan et al., Nanotechnology 20, 085612 (2009) [4] M.Zschintsch et al., Journal of Applied Physics, in print, (2010)

figure.head: Fig. 2 :
figure.figDesc: Fig. 2: TEM micrograph of the sample 169, annealed to T=600 O C, the particles have an average distance of more then the observed distance of 25nm.
